acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. As relevant information, a LD50 value is 11300 mg/kg bw for rabbits (RTECS (2006)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the toxicity value for rats LCLo <100 mg/m3/5h (= 22.3 ppm/4h; 0.112 mg/L/4h), LC100 = 6450 mg/m3/50min (= 586 ppm/4h; 2.938 mg/L/4h) (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 1. Although there is data of LCLo = 122000 mg/m3/1h (12.18 ppm/4h; 61 mg/L/4h), this data was not used as the basis of classification since there is a report of "Inhalation at high concentration caused immediate fatalities with pulmonary edema" in the same document. Since saturated vapour pressure concentration is 48684 ppm (244.16 mg/L), the test was considered to be conducted for vapour with almost no included mists and classification criteria for gas was adopted.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 1070 mg/kg bw for rats (PATTY (5th, 2001)), the substance was classified into Category 4.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Information is available that the substance corrodes most of the metals in presence of water (IMDG (2006)).

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified into Category 2 since flash point 20 degC (closed-cup) (ICSC (2003), Sax (11th, 2004)) is <23 degC and initial boiling point 105 degC (Howard (1997)) is >35 degC.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance is an organic compound containing chlorine and oxygen (but not fluorine) which are chemically bonded only to carbon.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is 535 degC (Ullmanns (E) (6th, 2003)) exceeding 70 degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on a report that direct contact with the eye causes permanent corneal opacity in a rabbit test (PATTY (5th, 2001)), and reports that eye irritation and surface burns have been principal findings in exposed humans (HSDB (2003)) and that this substance is irritating and corrosive to the eyes (HSDB (2003)), the substance was classified into Category 1. As relevant information, the substance was classified as a skin corrosive substance.

skin_corrosion_irritation.hazard_statement: Causes severe skin burns and eye damage
skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on a report that direct dropwise application to the skin causes deep necrosis and eschar formation in a guinea pig test (PATTY (5th, 2001)) and a report of "irritating and corrosive to the skin" (HSDB (2003)), the substance was classified into Category 1.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the following reports: (a) inhalation exposure in elevated concentrations cause death by immediate pulmonary edema and lower concentrations cause respiration distress, prostration, and convulsions (PATTY (5th, 2001)), (b) inhalation of 122,000 ppm (61 mg/L) by rats caused immediate fatalities with pulmonary edema and inhalation of 6450 ppm/50 min (1.344 mg/L/4h, within the guidance value range for Category 2) caused death of all rats with respiratory distress, prostration, and convulsions (PATTY (5th, 2001), HSDB (2003)), and (c) the substance is irritating and corrosive to the respiratory tract and exposure can cause delayed acute lung injury (HSDB (2003)); the substance was classified into Category 2 (respiratory system).
